comment.author: 68061336@N05
comment._content: Commonwealth War Graves Commission details Name: WILLIAMS, SAMUEL LLEWELLYN F. Initials: S L F Nationality: United Kingdom Rank: Private Regiment/Service: Royal Welsh Fusiliers Unit Text: 10th Bn. Age: 20 Date of Death: 26/09/1917 Service No: 44137 Additional information: Son of Pryce and Mary Williams, of 9, Marl View, Marl Lane, Deganwy, Carnarvonshire. Casualty Type: Commonwealth War Dead Grave/Memorial Reference: Panel 63 to 65. Memorial: TYNE COT MEMORIAL can be found here www.cwgc.org/search/casualty_details.aspx?casualty=877340

comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content:
Born about 1898 Stourbridge, Worcestershire. The 1911 census records him 13 years old and  living at 9 Marl View Terrace, [off Marl Lane] Deganwy, with his parents Pryce Williams [b.1872 Llangastener, Caernarvon] – a Road man for Conway Corporation and Mary Williams [b.1871 Stourbridge, Worcestershire]. He is their only child.
He enlisted on 24th May 1816 at Bangor, North Wales when he was 18 years and 8 months old.
His medical record indicated that he was 5ft 3 tall and weighed just over 8 stone and that he had no upper teeth
He was posted to France on the 23rd December 1916 embarking on 25th December 1916.
On the 19th March 1918 his personal effects consisting of personal letters, a cigarette case, two religious books and a silk [post?] card were sent to his father. Another piece of correspondence states that the effects were a postcard, a Gospel, photographs and a pamphlet.
His father died in 1946 at Builth, Breconshire.
The property still exists.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/liits/6669621033/in/photostream]
